Article.ArticleTitle: The reaction of isotope-substituted hydrated iodide I(HO)<sup>-</sup> with ozone: the reactive influence of the solvent water molecule.

AbstractText: We report an investigation of the reaction of isotope-substituted hydrated iodide I(HO)<sup>-</sup> with ozone <sup>16</sup>O<sub>3</sub> to examine the involvement of the water molecules in the oxidation reactions that terminate with the formation of IO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>. Experimentally, we studied the reaction in the gas phase as elementary reactions using a radio-frequency (RF) ion-trap combined with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS). In approximately 1.2% of the reactions of I(HO)<sup>-</sup> and <sup>16</sup>O<sub>3</sub>, the <sup>18</sup>O atom is found to appear in iodine oxide anions, thus giving evidence for a close involvement of the water molecule in a non-negligible number of the reactions towards IO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>. As a part of the experimental investigation, the reaction rate constant for the exchange reaction I(HO)<sup>-</sup> + HO → I(HO)<sup>-</sup> + HO at 300 K was found to be (1.3 ± 0.1) × 10<sup>-8</sup> cm<sup>3</sup> s<sup>-1</sup>. Quantum chemical calculations are exploited to establish the energetic difference between I(HO)<sup>-</sup> and I(HO)<sup>-</sup>.
